posts.sub: cooking for my coeliac sister with nut allergies
posts.com:
>tfw removed from /ck/ twice
hey /adv/
my half-sister is going to stay with me for about a month and she can't eat gluten or nuts. any advice on what to cook for her while she stays over? she likes sweet shit and I want to spoil her while she's here.
recipes much appreciated.
thanks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28055180
Lmao this thread is perfect for me, I have a severe general nut allergy and had to inject myself with an epipen only 8 days ago.
To start with I recommend a chicken jalfrezi curry with rice, this dish is really tasty and doesnt contain gluten or nuts:
https://www.bbcgoodfood.com/recipes/chicken-jalfrezi
personally. one of my favourites is a good ratatouille, serve with rice or roasted potatoes and bits of melted mozzarella and it should go down well : https://www.bbcgoodfood.com/recipes/ratatouille
If you want something sweet to try for a main get a gluten free bbq sauce and combine it with some pulled pork and rice and veggies very tasty: https://glutenfreeonashoestring.com/bbq-sauce/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28055180
oh, anon. this is so kind of you. i also have celiac disease, a guy made me some special gluten-free cookies, it really made my day i never forgot it.
there are some interesting desserts you can create that she can eat, but you aren't very detailed in this post and you use the word "cook" rather than "bake." stuff like flan, panna cotta, and other pudding/jelly things contain no gluten at all, so you don't need to adjust them for her and they would be great for spoiling, however, this all kind of relies on personal preferences. there are plenty of excellent recipes available for baking and gluten replacements and whole sites dedicated to this concept ^^ i don't know how to bake or cook well, but i found several interesting gluten-free desserts that i want to try. just the titles will be included so that the links don't get marked as spam...

these ones are all posted by "Meaningful Eats":
>Perfect Gluten-Free Cupcake Recipe
>Gluten-Free Strawberry Cream Cheese Trifle (this one looks good)
>Gluten-Free Apple Crisp
>Gluten-Free Chocolate Caramel Tart

if she has any more allergies or if i didn't read through the recipes clear enough, you should come up with some creative replacements for ingredients. these all seem good to me and are sweet. dinners for me are generally anything without gluten in it, which is probably difficult to understand for those who live off of pasta or other grainslop, but for me, simply combining some meat, great flavour, sauce, aromatics, and vegetables is always good enough! have fun and i hope she enjoys it if you make any of these desserts :3

>>28056560
hi i'm back and since your sister is 13, there are additional kid-friendly, nostalgic, or just adorable foods for her. since there is a limitless supply of these kinds of recipes, i'm curious to see what you'll make. now you make me jealous because i wish i had a sibling to make me these treats kek

>Gluten Free Dairy Free Dirt Cake - Iowagirleats (not a vegan, and i'm dubious about the flavour if you go that path, but a skilled chef or baker needs to be good at amounts and substitutions, especially for persons with delicate stomachs. still, this worms dirt cake recipe is just timeless. absolute classic that every child should experienceat least once.)
>Gluten-Free S'mores - Food network
>Cacao Coconut Bliss Balls Recipe - Kidspot
>Sweet Potato Brownies Recipe - Kidspot

great recipes and options for gluten-free food can be found on the kidspot website. you're a great brother! :3 regarding the worries about the cookies sticking together, try especially searching online for the recipes with the best ratings because sometimes xanthan gum is required to produce something gluten-free while maintaining the same level of hold, and it might be challenging to find these ingredients. therefore, if you want to create a specific type of cookie, keep an eye out for reviews and accounts of the texture since it is a challenge when baking gluten-free... but things like puddings never fail. also, if she enjoys eggs, make some for her and use ketchup to draw something on them. that was something very sweet that my father always did for me. he used to draw funny faces and write my name. :')

posts.com: One thing that is kind of important is avoiding cross contamination - apparently using the same chopping boards, knives etc that you do to prep gluten containing meals on can end up making someone with celiac disease sick. I don't know if she has that or if she's just intolerant, but it's worth nothing.

Here's a cope:
Normies have existential safety in numbers. Their greatest ego defence is blending in, and for that, no matter how smart or interesting they are, they are always going to be dishonest about their achievements. Every ant in the bridge made of ants is allowed credit to take the entire thing as his own doing when he goes off to visit other colonies - he's just a link in a chain, not even a sheep in a herd.
I'm not saying you're special, but people who grow slowly or divergently are player characters by proxy, because it's easy to explain the motives of an NPC - you just read the manual - whereas, the way the user controlled character keeps bumping into the same specific wall... there's definitely a human pulling the strings. Even if you fail, you're in the game. Doesn't matter how you play it. But that is the one thing you have that normies don't. Your defectiveness is a mark of authenticity among the sleek, clean profiles of the homogenous mass. A normie trying to say "uh no you're not special" is like saying a pair of jeans that come with ripped knees from the factory is at all like a pair of jeans that were ripped because someone made a mistake at work. Yet, the latter drives the desire of the former.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28052542
>Marriage is not necessary for commitment
Yes, it is, or at least some kind of structure is. Marriage is the social institution that's provided the structure for millennia, so I'll stick with that.

> it's very telling of you though that you think commitment is only possible in marriage
You're using commitment in a different sense than I am:
To you, it is being dedicated to one course of action or another. It's a subjective feeling. Important for a good marriage, obviously, but it's not measurable and it's certainly not consistent.
Moral standards are designed to be both. That's how they work.
This is why I use commitment in the objective sense: being bound to a course of action by *external* forces. Marriage is (and should be) the mechanism by which commitment is standardized and enforced. Things like infidelity or abandonment can be punished if someone breaks their commitment only in this formal sense. The only thing that happens if they break their subjective feeling of commitment is a guilty conscience.

Basically, what you're saying is that laws aren't necessary because some--even most--people wouldn't do erstwhile prohibited things by their nature. Or that guardrails on a cliffside road aren't necessary because most people are good drivers. This is fallacious reasoning. It replaces standards which both guide behavior and protect against negative consequences with pure fatalism, simply waiting until things happen for better or worse and then calling them good or bad after the fact. A lack of any formal commitment works just fine, like with your couples--until the moment it doesn't. Then that lack of commitment shows, and the damage is much greater because you ignored insurance on the assumption you wouldn't need it.

tl;dr Saying you're above rules because you wouldn't break them is hubris. Society needs them, and if you wouldn't break them anyway, it wouldn't hurt you to set a good example.

Also, for someone who harps about missing variables, you really don't get what waiting until marriage is, do you? It's not just about virginity. It's about approaching relationships in a way that is much more focused on commitment. Waiting until marriage doesn't mean you marry the first virgin you come across. It means you don't have sex until you're married; you can still date multiple people to find the one you want to marry, and because you aren't doing anything (sex, living together, sharing major financial burdens) until you commit, the only reason you have to stay together is how well you get along as people. It's not hard to see how this *approach*, of which virginity until marriage is a feature and byproduct, might be beneficial to the overall success of marriages.

Moreover, the REASON for someone to take this approach isn't just its benefits for marriage, but because of what it helps to realize marriage as: an exclusive lifelong bond with your spouse. By only giving yourself to your spouse after you've committed to stay together, you make it far more likely that you will be monogamous in the deepest and most intimate way, of only ever having been with each other. This ideal would be worth it even if there were no practical difference in the success rates of marriages between those who waited and those who didn't. That waiting until marriage ALSO benefits marriages directly is an added bonus, and a refutation of people like you who ignorantly insist that it's somehow a bad idea.

>>28057801
If the middle value has historically been well above 20, then whatever idea you have of "trad" women needing to be married that early is wrong. Clearly, a large portion of society could marry later. That was my sole point--while marrying earlier than 30 is important, there is a historical basis in "trad" societies for marrying later without being seen as unusual.

The idea that you need to get married right out of high school to be trad is counterproductive (particularly in modern conditions, which are comparable to the most urbanized and financially taxing situations in the past--making later marital ages unsurprising for anyone). It largely defeats the purpose of waiting until marriage, because rushing into marriage and marrying very young are both major risk factors for divorce. Statistically, marrying before around 22 carries significantly heightened risk, with each year before that increasing the risk even more. Marrying around 26 is the best when only age of marriage is taken into account, but obviously it's okay to marry earlier if a couple who waited is ready.

But that's the key point: if they're ready. Waiting until marriage doesn't mean you'll end up with the first person you date, and it may take some time to find the right person. For example, say you start seriously looking around 20, take half a year to find someone, but that first relationship ends in a breakup after a year. Then say you're single for another 6-12 months before finding the person you'd end up marrying. If you stay prudent and wait about 2 years (much sooner than that also is a risk factor) to tie the knot, then you're already almost 25 at marriage, even though there is nothing remarkable about that kind of relationship history.

A woman isn't a failure for being smart enough to take her time in finding a decent husband; telling her to rush into marriage by 22, "or else", is counterproductive for both the standard of waiting and the end result of marriage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28060174
First you have to become aware of your self-image. It’s an image you have in your mind of who you are. The way to change is by imagining a new image. And then you look at your behaviours, and ask yourself whether you are acting out your old self-image/identity, or whether you’re acting out your new one. Keep the new one in your head as you act the new way. It should feel renewing and spacious for you to do it. It should make you look at yourself with fresh eyes, suddenly aware of all the possibilities. The main obstacle is a feeling of resistance. You’ll notice it as a feeling that you’re not supposed to do it, you’re not allowed to let yourself feel like a person who makes good friendships for example. Find out where that resistance comes from, and honestly knife it and stuff it down the toilet.

Security and certainty that you can be something new and fresh will not just be given to you. If you leave it to its own devices, you will become filled with doubt and you will give up. You have to snap up and scent of doubt. Don’t try to just ignore it. You have to learn to defeat it. And you’re going to go back to scratch several times in this process, and that’s normal. Keep imagining this new self-image as you act it out, and destroy the resistance and uncertainty. As long as you cannot let yourself imagine someone new, you will never change. Whose permission do you need?

From there, it’s all about your values, reciprocity, intent, looking at what the other person needs, and sharing with them of your world. And basically the people you will befriend are the ones who you can offer something they want, and they can offer something you want, in the most autistic of terms.

For example, the friends I gathered in my youth were losers like myself. What I had to offer was having a little humor and lightness about being a loser, and low expectations. Now I have different values, and by getting good at embodying them, I have found reciprocation

I think the internet has sucked any joy and excitement I had for the world. When I was 19-21 I used to want to meet interesting people, have quirky hobbies, lots of friends, experiences, travel but didn't really get to properly do any of this because of social anxiety and the pandemic.
Concurrently, within the past couple of years, I've had every idiosyncratic though of mine mirrored through the internet and seen every iteration of "my future self" do every single thing by either very obnoxious people that put me off those things, or just normalised them in a way where, if I still wanted to follow through, it would be a case of "you really had to do all that huh" basically meaning I'd need to become obnoxious myself to unapologetically follow through.
In retrospect, none of these desires were remotely unique, but the thing is my desire for life is gone not just for "quirky" things but normal ones as well, such as friendships, relationships, books. It's not just the internet - there were other developments in my life that led to this, and perhaps just a budding sense of adult cynicism or being over it. But to a point I think having such a direct access to people's inner thoughts has made my own a lot less special and more negligible than it would have 20 years ago.

This is obviously inconsequential in the grand scheme of things but I am literally about to board the plane for a week trip to visit a friend in a European town where we'll go out to restaurants etc. but I have 0 wonder or joy and would rather just stay at home and never leave my town. What do I do

My boyfriend and I had a similar dynamic, we started out so happy and affectionate towards each other, but as my anxiety kept me from doing the things I wanted to and turned me into a shut in, he became more and more frustrated with me. The thing is, I never knew I had anxiety - panic attacks, yes, but not anxiety - so he thought I was just a coward and I believed him, and it just seemed no matter how much advice and help he tried to give, none of it worked (because I didn't just have normal fear). He left me about two months ago after I kept breaking promises to him and he eventually said that I'd never be able to change and left me. This isn't the first time he's done it, but it's been the longest he's been gone and he pretty much hates me now. Of course, my anxiety and panic attacks have gotten so much worse without him, since him leaving is basically my worst nightmare, but I've managed to learn more about my anxiety and am going into therapy soon.
So, with that out of the way, what I would say is first of all, learn more about your mental illness, and second of all, TELL him about it. Get him to read a book about it, or parts of a book, which is what I would do with my bf if he were here. He was the sweetest, most loving person in the world, but I brought out the worst in him because of my untreated mental illness (and his own issues probably made it worse). So, if he is willing to be this patient with you now, you can know that he's definitely a keeper and would want to help you. Don't leave this problem unattended like I did, or you could risk losing him like me. Personally, I think we're gonna get back together one day, but you never know, so just don't let it get this bad in the first place.

No.
>Its usually something very small that causes it and then the other issues spring up.
Usually means you only talk about important things while fighting.
My suggestion - set up a place that is semi-public and a set time to discuss how you feel and what is bothering you. For example,
>front porch in a subdivision, Tuesday from 6 pm to 7 pm
No shouting, no interrupting each other, no cursing. Just discussing what you otherwise don't discuss. If someone is overwhelmed they leave and the other person lets them go

Couples therapy is just a professional helping you do the same thing, but it could help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28053735
Having a successful marriage is like having a successful business. Yes, there are things you can do to increase the likelihood of having one, but one of the biggest components to being married for 20 years or being rich is pure luck. Asking for advice from these people is mostly worthless because both you and they are affected by survivorship bias and you'll just get generic stuff like
>>28053756
>communicate and be nice to one another
or a successful businessman telling you that you need to work hard and be devoted to success. Meanwhile, there are countless failed marriages where both partners did everything right but it still didn't work out, just like there are countless failed businesses despite the owners working themselves to death.

These people think that they're successful because they did something that the people who failed didn't do. The reality is that both the winners and the losers were doing the same things, but one group was lucky and the other wasn't.

posts.name: MarriedOldfag
posts.com:
>>28054121
Your mention of 'survivorship bias', though, is a real problem.
Survivorship bias does NOT mean
>you can't learn anything from survivors
It DOES mean
>the lessons from survivors can only be understood by comparison with the failures
Yes, "communicate", "be nice", "don't take each other for granted" sound trite but despite your claims 'it is all luck' we can point to millions of *failed* marriages to say that if you do NOT do these things you will fail and not because of luck.
Yes, successful businessmen were dedicated to their business and worked hard. But the people who were not dedicated and did not work hard have no real chance of success, regardless of luck.
Your complaint is akin to saying
>"'keep your eye on the ball' is nonsense because lots of people who do never make it to the Hall of Fame"

Nearly everybody wants to get married one day. The problem is that you can't possibly tell in the early stages of a relationship whether things are going to work well enough for that to happen. The only way it's going to work is if you go into it with no particular expectation that it will work out IN THIS CASE and see how things go. If they go really well, then perhaps you'll end up getting married; if not, you may end up splitting up; that's just part of the process.

It's reasonable to say up front that you're not looking for a one night stand, or for something casual; but it's a problem if you're thinking in terms of "I want something really serious and permanent right away". You can't make serious and permanent happen immediately; it takes time to develop. A refusal to acknowledge that is definitely a red flag - people who instantly become obsessive about you are are scary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28060032
>If she's genuinely submissive, she'll do whatever I tell her, won't she?
I suppose I should address that in more detail.

First off, no sub in the world will do "whatever you tell her". Every sub has limits; and every good dom will respect those limits absolutely.

But in practice it often goes well beyond just having limits. Many subs are extremely demanding; they have a very narrow, precisely defined, range of things they want to be told to do, and have zero interest in stepping outside that. In BDSM communities, it's standard practice to draw up a written "contract" listing exactly what you are and aren't comfortable with before you play for the first time.

On top of that, the fact that a woman is submissive, doesn't necessarily mean that she will want to be submissive WITH YOU - imagining that she automatically will is like assuming that she will want to have sex with you just because she's straight. Submissives only want to submit to specific people who bring that out of them. And different people can bring a submissive streak out of you in different ways; so the same activity may be incredibly hot with one person, but repulsive with another. Some people are dominant with some partners and submissive with others; some like to switch it up with the same partner; and so on.

Basically, it's a lot more complicated than you're imagining.

>What kind of things do people typically associate with humiliation in those scenes?
Humiliation tends to be an extremely precise fetish - there's a very narrowly-defined range of things the person enjoys. But exactly what that is will vary enormously from person to person. I have a friend, for example, who has a very specific thing about being compared unfavourably to other women - she likes being told that her breasts are saggy, and that the guy can barely bring himself to touch her because she's so disgusting, and that he would be enjoying it so much more if he were with someone else. The tone of voice that he adopts is very important - I've known her break up with guys just because the sound of their voice wasn't doing it for her. But many other people who have a humiliation fetish would look at that and say "I can't imagine finding that a turn-on" because they're more into wearing a collar and leash, or being "made" to drink lots of water and then having to stand there fully dressed until they lose control of their bladder. It's different for everyone - there's no such thing as "typical" when it comes to humiliation.

>>28055408
It's the inflammation induced by airborne carcinogens that increases the risk of oncogenesis (tumor formation). It's often the case that the chemicals and fire retardants in carpets and other furniture are the culprits for this but proving causation is nearly impossible. The body has multiple methods of ridding the body of these particles from the body: the cilia in the lungs, mucous production, sneezing, coughing up phlegm as well as the assorted traps in the nasal and sinus passages which keep the majority of carcinogens from entering the lungs to begin with. The immune system also encapsulates inflammation-inducing particles and processes them through the lymphatic system and then to the blood and the liver for neutralization and removal from the body.

The lungs are a also one of the body's largest stores of the molecule glutathione which is the body's master oxidant. Each and every cell in your body has numerous glutathione molecules within them which help neutralize reactive oxygen species and other free radicals which may come into contact with cellular membrane or enter the cells itself. So long as glutathione levels remain at a sustained level carcinogens which enter the pulmonary system will be readily handled. However, persistent exposure to carcinogens can begin to wear down and oxidize glutathione below baseline levels which is when apoptosis (cell death) and inflammation occurs, raising the possibility of oncogenesis. Glutathione can be readily repleted (returned to its reduced, unoxidized state) so long as there's a persistent supply of the amino acid cysteine which is the rate-limiting precursor to glutathione repletion. Cysteine, however, is in short supply in the body and can be depleted during periods of stress among other things. Supplementing with N-Acetyl-Cysteine can help restore glutathione levels in the lungs which will prevent glutathione levels from dropping below baseline levels needed to maintain proper pulmonary health.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Naltrexone for addiction treatment

An addict wanting and trying to quit is a case of the rational mind deciding to stop, while the autonomous processes of the mind create cravings. Its why people have such a hard time losing weight. Rational mind chooses to lose weight and eat less, autonomous mind sends craving signals. One can understand a behavior is worth quitting and try his best to quit, yet repeatedly fail against incessant, powerful urges. Worth noting is that gambling, sex, compulsive overeating, alcoholism and drug addiction are a cluster of similar disorders. A malfunction of the brain's "reward center". See for yourself: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18241634/

Naltrexone is a helpful medication to remove the cravings. Classed as an opiate-antagonist (binds to endorphin receptors w/out "high"), Naltrexone comes in a once-monthly injection or daily pills. Absent insurance, injection is expensive and pills are inexpensive. Public health clinics, aka "community clinics" receive federal and state cost-reduction grants to serve people who lack insurance. Sliding-fee scale for most services and in the case of Naltrexone injection, often free. In the U.S. you can call 211 in most cities, a direct line to United Way. They will help you locate such a clinic. Also some anti-depressants and other psychotropic medications can help. Addicts tend to have mood or other psychiatric issues that are called "co-morbid factors". A doctor at a "community clinic" can help

Anyway, both police and fire hire in certain time windows so I've been having to wait to take entry exams. posts.com: Social media is one of the gayest things ever created. Imagine going online and posting pictures of yourself, your day to day affairs, the shit you buy, the food you eat... all just so a bunch of people who don't give a fuck about you will see it and show faux enthusiasm for the activities of your boring, mundane, detestable life; only because they hope you'll do the same thing for them. You want to know who your real friends are? Delete your Facebook, Twitter, stop using Snapchat, all of that garbage, and magically you will see 99% of the people in your life disappear overnight. It will astound you just how few people care about reaching out to you if you're only available by phone or email. If you want to improve your life, one of the best things you can do is delete all forms of social media other than those necessary for work. If that makes you feel lonely and isolated, then good; you'll understand how alone you've been the entire time.
